And it is only with such a possibility that there could be room for the advice contained in the present verse. What harm could there be in the author making still clearer what he has already said before (regarding the regulation of the optional alternatives)?

Some people hold thatтАФeven after the prescribed number of days have elapsed, purification is not accomplished until bathing and other rites have been performed; as it is going to be asserted that тАШthe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa becomes pure after touching water, etc.тАЩ (Verse 98); and some one may think that so long as he remains impure he would not incur any sin by the omission of religious duties, and hence he may not proceed to take the bath or other rites;тАФand it is in view of such cases that we have the injunction that тАШone should not prolong the days of impurity,тАЩтАФthe meaning being that the stipulated days having elapsed, one should not delay the external purifications.

As regards the assertion thatтАФтАЬthe use of the term day implies that there is no impurity on the night of the tenth day,тАЭтАФit has already been pointed out that this view is not correct. Says Gautama (14.6)тАФтАШIf during one impurity another source of impurity should arise, there is purification after the remainder of the formerтАЩ; and having said this, he thought that people might be led to think that if the second impurity should arise about the end of the last night, there would be purification after that night, and in order to guard against this he has addedтАФтАШif it happens about the end of the night, then after two nightsтАЩ (14.7) [From which it is dear that the lost night also falls within the period of impurity].

тАШNor should he interrupt the rites performed in the fires.тАЩтАФThis is said in view of the fact by reason of impurity all the rites prescribed in the ┼Ъruti and the Smс╣Ыti become precluded. The meaning is that the rites that are performed in the fires,тАФsuch as the Evening-libation and the restтАФshould not be interrupted,тАФi.e., shall not be omitted. тАШInterruptionтАЩ means omission, non-per formance.

But this does not mean that the impure man should himself perform the rites; since it is addedтАФтАШhe who performs the rites, even if he be a Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa, would never be impureтАЩ; which means that тАШeven a Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa-relation would not be impure, to say nothing of other personsтАЩ; says the Gс╣Ыhyas┼лtra alsoтАФтАШThey should perform in the house-fire the obligatory rites, with the exception of the Vait─Бna -riteтАЩ; and thenтАФтАШothers would perform these.тАЩ This does not refer to the mere offering of libations that is done in connection with the setting up of the fires, but to the performance of the rite in all its details; since it is only for these that the employment of other agents is possible, since the principal libation itself, which consists in offering certain substances, can be offered by the householder himself. Hence the rites that are precluded (daring impurity) are those of the Vai┼Ыvadeva-offering and the Dar┼Ыa-P┼лrс╣Зam─Бsa and other sacrifices. Of other nets, such as the telling of beads, the saying of Twilight Prayers and so forth,тАФthe preclusion of these has nowhere been indicated; and all these are obligatory. Hence what the present taxt does is to permit the performance of other acts; specially as another Smс╣Ыti text has prohibited such acts as тАШthe offering of libations and Vedic study.тАЩ Thus then, the distinction (as to what acts are precluded and what not) is based upon the obligatory or voluntary character of the acts themselves; specially as the voluntary act tending to the accomplishment of desired ends should never be done, since impurity deprives the man of the title to perform all such acts.

тАЬBut the impure man cannot be entitled to the performance of the obligatory acts either.тАЭ

As a matter of fact, purity does not constitute an essential factor in the rites; and though an obligatory act may be done even in a slightly deficient form (due to the lack of purity, for instance), such is not permissible in the case of voluntary acts done with a view to definite ends. It might be argued that they also might be performed, on the strength of the present text itself. But this would not be right; for all that the present text permits is getting certain rites performed by proxy; and as this in itself would be a deficiency, it would be admissible in the case of the obligatory rites only, and not in that of voluntary ones.

With regard to the Vai┼Ыvadeva offering however, there is a difference of opinion. Some people quote the following Smс╣Ыti -textтАФтАШAt a birth or a death, one shall not pour libations into fire, even with dry grains or fruits, nor should he perform any sacrificial rites.тАЩ

From all this it follows that one should offer the following the Twilight-libations, the D┼лr┼Ыa-Purс╣Зam─Бsa sacrifices, the Annual ┼Ъr─Бddha, the ┼Ъr─Бddha offered in the month of ─А┼Ыvina and so forth. As for the Up─Бkarma, its performance depends upon the lunar asterism and it need not be done on the full-moon-day.тАФ(83.)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(Verse 84 of others.)

тАШPraty┼лhenс╣Е─Бgniс╣гu kriy─Бс╕етАЩтАФMedh─Бtithi has been misrepresented here, not only by Buhler, but by Kull┼лka also. There is nothing in Medh─Бtithi to show that Sandhyop─Бsana should be omitted for ten days. Nor is there any difference in the interpretation of Medh─Бtithi and that of Kull┼лka and others. (See Translation.)

тАШSan─Бbhayaс╕етАЩтАФтАШSapiс╣Зс╕НaтАЩ (Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and R─Бghav─Бnanda);тАФтАШSahodaraтАЩ, тАШuterine brotherтАЩ (Nandana).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 891), which adds the following notes:тАФWith a view to remaining idle, without having to perform his religious duties, one should not prolong the days of impurity; nor should he abandon those necessary acts that are prescribed to be performed in the ┼Ыrauta fires,тАФe.g., the Agnihotra offerings; the meaning is that all those should be done even during the days of impurity;тАФthe second half is added in anticipation of the objection that тАЬin view of the rule whereby impure men are not entitled to the performance of religious acts, it would be right to abandon the acts during the period of impurity.тАЭ What is meant is that it is quite true that the impure m an should not perform religious acts; but on the strength of the special texts (like the present one) hearing upon certain Well defined acts, one would be justified in concluding that he is not тАШimpureтАЩ, so far as the performance of these acts is concerned.тАФThe use of Atmanepada form тАШkurv─Бс╣Зaс╕етАЩ makes it clear that the actual performer of the religions acts is not impureтАФeven though the person dead or born be a very near relation of his,тАФin fact he is quite pure. Inasmuch as this absence of impurity refers to the performer himself, it follows that so far as officiating at the performance of other persons is concerned, the near relations of the dead or the born must be regarded as impure and unqualified.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 3.17), in support of the view that there is no impurity regarding the performance of those religious acts that are compulsory, the voluntary ones, however, which are done for the purpose of gaining reward, should not be performed during impurity;тАФand it adds that since the text specifically mentions the acts done тАШin the firesтАЩ, it follows that the тАШfive great sacrifices,тАЩ which are not done in fire, should cease during impurity.

It is quoted in Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 254) as affording justification for the coalescing of тАШimpuritiesтАЩ due to more than one cause;тАФin H─Бralat─Б (pp. 7 and 25), which notes that the expression тАШtat karmaтАЩ implies that the impurity means incapacity to perform such acts as Fire-kindling, gifts, Homa and so forth, and adds the following notes:тАФтАШagh─Бh─БniтАЩ, days of impurity, those should not be prolonged by the Agnihotrin, for whom its curtailment is justified by distinct texts; and he should never observe the full period of ten days,тАФeven dining the curtailed period, he should not entirely stop the offerings into the Fires, he should have this done through Br─Бhmaс╣Зas belonging to other gotras and hence not suffering from the same disabilities,тАФand the reason for this lies in the fact that in the performance of the said acts of disablity does not attach even to the Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa,тАФwhat to say of persons of other gotras?

It is quoted also in Gad─Бdharapaddhati (K─Бla, p. 278), which explains тАШsan─Бbhayaс╕етАЩ as Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa,тАФтАШtatkarmaтАЩ as officiating as a priest,тАФthe disability due to impurity does hot attach to him, if no person of other gotras is available for the work,тАФsuch is the implication of the particle тАШapiтАЩ.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (3.17).тАФтАШOne should continue to perform all the fire-worship, as also all those acts that are enjoined in the Veda.тАЩ

Vy─Бghrap─Бt (Apar─Бrka, p. 892).тАФтАШDuring the period of impurity one should stop all sm─Бrta rites; but for the purpose of ┼Ыrauta rites, one becomes pure immediately, by bathing.тАЩ

P─Бraskara Gс╣Ыhyas┼лtra (3.13.31-34).тАФтАШDuring the period of impurity, one should not carry on Vedic study one should intermit the daily rites, with the exception of those performed with the help of the ┼Ыrauta fire, or with that of the domestic fire, according to some:тАФothers should perform those for him.тАЩ

J─Бb─Бla (Apar─Бrka, p. 892).тАФтАШDuring the impurity due to birth and death, there is no intermission of rites performed in the ┼Ыrauta fire; as regards the domestic fire, libations into it should be poured by persons belonging to another gotra.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Do.).тАФтАШDuring impurity due to birth or to death, one shall not abandon the fire-offerings, he shall have them offered by others.тАЩ

J─Бt┼лkarс╣Зya (Do.).тАФтАШDuring an impurity, Piс╣Зс╕Нayaj├▒a, Caru-Yaj├▒a, and Homa, should be got done by a person not belonging to the same gotra.тАЩ

Saс╣Гvarta, (Do.).тАФтАШThe Homa-offerings should, during impurity, be made with dry grains or fruits; but the performance of the five Great Sacrifices should be intermitted. For ten days, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall desist from the Vai┼Ыvadeva offering.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зupur─Бс╣Зa (Do.).тАФтАШO king, the offering of the twilight-prayers should he done at all times, except during impurity.тАЩ

Paiс╣нh─лnasi (Do.).тАФтАШDuring impurity, one shall only offer water with the S─Бvitr─л and meditating upon the sun, offer his obeisance.тАЩ

Pulastya (Do. p. 893).тАФтАШThe twilight-prayers, the Iс╣гс╣нi, the Caru and Homa one should perform all through life; even during impurity one shall not omit these During impurity due to death or birth, one should not omit the twilight prayers; the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall repeat the mantras only mentallyтАФeven so omitting the Breath-suspension.тАЩ

B├╝hler

084 Let him not (unnecessarily) lengthen the period of impurity, nor interrupt the rites to be performed with the sacred fires; for he who performs that (Agnihotra) rite will not be impure, though (he be) a (Sapinda) relative.

рдХреНрд╖реБрджреНрд░рд╛рд╢реМрдЪрд╛рдирд┐

085 рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рдореН рдЙрджрдХреНрдпрд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рджрд┐рд╡рд╛-рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рдореН+++(=рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рдВ)+++, рдЙрджрдХреНрдпрд╛рдВ+++(=рд░рдЬрд╕реНрд╡рд▓рд╛рдВ)+++ рдЪ
рдкрддрд┐рддрдВ, рд╕реВрддрд┐рдХрд╛рдВ рддрдерд╛ ред
рд╢рд╡рдВ, рддрддреН-рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдирдВ, рдЪреИрд╡
рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛ рд╕реНрдирд╛рдиреЗрди рд╢реБрдзреНрдпрддрд┐ рее рел.реорел рее [реорек рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

After having touched the C─Бnd─Бla, the menstruating woman, the outcast, the woman in child-bed, the dead body, or toucher thereofтАФone becomes pure by bathing.тАФ(84).

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рдГ, рдЕрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд╛рд╢реБрдЪрд┐рд╕рд╛рд╣рдЪрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рднрд╛рд░рддреЗ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рдиреН рдорд╛рд░реНрдЬрд╛рд░рдореВрд╖рд┐рдХрд╕рдВрд╡рд╛рджреЗ ред

  • рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЪ рдХрд╛рд▓реЗ рд╜рднреВрджреН рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐рд░реН рднрдпрд╛рд░реНрджрд┐рддрдГ ред рдЗрддрд┐ ред (рдореНрднреН резреи.резрейрем.резрежрем)

рди рдирд╛рдкрд┐рддрдГ, рддрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрдкреГрд╢реНрдпрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рднреЛрдЬреНрдпрд╛рдиреНрдирддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЪ ред рдпрддреН рддреБ рд╢реНрдорд╢реНрд░реБрдХрд░реНрдордгрд┐ рддрд╕реНрдпреЗрджрдВ рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрд╣реБрд╕реН рддрджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдпрдореН ред рдЕрд╡рд╢реНрдпрдВ193 рд╢реНрдорд╢реНрд░реБрдХрд░реНрдорд╛рдгрд┐ рдХрд╛рд░рдпрддреЛ рд░реЛрдорд╛рдгрд┐ рдЧрд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд┐ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╢рдиреНрддрд┐, рддрд╛рдирд┐ рд╢рд░реАрд░рд╛рдЪреН рдЪреНрдпреБрддрд╛рдиреНрдпреН рдЕрд╢реБрджреНрдзрд╛рдиреАрддрд┐ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдВ рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдореН ред рддрддреНрд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдирдВ рддрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрдВ рддрддреНрд╕реНрдкреГрддрдореН, рддрджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрддреАрддрд┐ рддрддреНрд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯреА ред рдпреЗрдиреИрддреЗ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╕реН рддрджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирдореН рдПрд╡ ред

  • рдЗрд╣ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рд╕рддреНрддреЗрдГ рддрддреНрд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдирдореН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ рд╢рд╡рд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЖрд╣реБрд░реН рди рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рдХрд┐рд░реНрддреНрдпрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдореН ред

  • рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗ рддреБ рдПрдХрд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпреЛрдкрдирд┐рдкрд╛рддрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрддреЗ рд╢реНрд░реБрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдмреБрджреНрдзреМ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рддрдЪреНрдЫрдмреНрджреЗрди194 рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдирд╛рдореНрдирд╛ рдкрд░рд╛рдорд░реНрд╢ рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╣рд┐ рд╢рд╡рдкрд░реНрдпрдиреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рджреНрд╡рдиреНрджреНрд╡рдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯреАрддреНрдпреН рдЕрдиреЗрди рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ ред рддрддреНрд░ рддрддреНрд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯреАрддрд┐ рд╕рдорд╛рд╕рд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реНрдп рдмреБрджреНрдзреМ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рд╣рд┐рддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рддрдЪреНрдЫрдмреНрджреЗрдирд╛рд╡рдорд░реНрд╢рдГ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рд╕реНрдп рд╢рд╡рд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдкрджреЗрди195 рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзреЛ рд▓рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ, рдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░реН рдЗрддрд░реЗрддрд░рдпреБрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН196 ред рдХрд┐рдВ рддреБ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рд╕реНрдп рдкрджрд╛рдиреНрддрд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ ред рджреНрд╡рдиреНрджреНрд╡реЗ рд╣реНрдпреН рдПрдХреИрдХрдГ рд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рднрд┐рдзрд╛рдпреА ред рддрддрдГ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рд╕рдиреНрдирдГ ред рдЕрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рд╢рд╡рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рд╢рдмреНрджрд╕реНрдп рддрддреНрд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдкрджреЗрди рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рддрддреЛ рд╜рдиреНрдпреИрд░реН рдЕрднрд┐рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдГ ред рддрдерд╛ рд╕рддрд┐ рдкрддрд┐рддрд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рдкрджреЗрди рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзреЛ рди рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рд╕рдорд╛рдЪрд╛рд░рдд рдПрд╡ рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдпрдГ рее рел.реорек рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The тАШdiv─Бk─лrtiтАЩ is the c─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla; that it is so is clear from the fact that he is mentioned along with the worst untouchables, and also from the use of the name in the Mah─Бbh─Бrata, in course of a conversation between the Cat and the MouseтАФтАШat that time the Div─Бk─лrti became oppressed with fearтАЩ (where it is the c─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla that is clearly meant). It cannot stand for the barber here; for the barber is among the touchables, and also because he is one whose food may be eaten (by the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa). As for the rule laying down the necessity of bathing after a shave, this cannot be put forward in the present context, as the bathing in this case is necessitated by the consideration that, while one is shaving hairs are bound to fall on the body, and as, on falling from the body, they are unclean, it is necessary that one should bathe.

тАШTatspс╣Ыс╣гс╣нinamтАЩ, тАШthe toucher thereof.тАЩтАФThis compound is to be expounded asтАФтАШtasya spс╣Ыс╣гс╣нam, tadasy─БstiтАЩ. The men who touch those mentioned above have also got to bathe.

Some people argue that, as the persons mentioned are not all in equal proximity to the term тАШtatspс╣Ыс╣гс╣нinam,тАЩ тАШthe toucher thereof,тАЩ this refers to the тАШdead bodyтАЩ only, and not to the тАШC─Бс╣Зс╕Н─БlaтАЩ and the rest. But others hold that since all are mentioned in the same sentence, and since the term occurs at the end of all the other persons mentioned, all these are present before the mind, and hence referred to by the pronoun тАШthereofтАШ; so that the construction intended is that all the terms up to тАШ┼ЫaramтАЩ, тАШthe dead bodyтАЩ, form one copulative compound, and then compounded with тАШspс╣Ыс╣гс╣нinamтАЩ, тАШtoucherтАЩ; and hence when the term тАШthe toucher thereofтАЩ comes up, all the things spoken of by all the members of the copulative compound come to the mind. There is, on the other band, nothing to indicate that the term тАШtoucherтАЩ is to be connected with the тАШdead bodyтАЩ only; for the simple reason that it is equally connected with the тАШoutcastтАЩ and the rest also. In fact, all that is clearly indicated is that the term тАШtoucherтАЩ is connected with some other term that has gone before; in a copulative compound however, each term is regarded as denoting all the things spoken of; and hence all these latter are equally closely related to the term тАШtoucherтАЩ. Another construction that might be suggested is to construe the term тАШtoucher thereofтАЩ with the term тАШdead bodyтАЩ, and then with the other terms. But in this case, there would be nothing to justify the connection of the term тАШtoucherтАЩ with the тАШoutcastтАЩ and the rest.

From all this it follows that it is only on the strength of usage that a right conclusion can be arrived at.тАФ(84)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(Verse 85 of others.)

тАШTatspс╣Ыс╣гс╣нinamтАЩтАФтАШOne who has touched these, i.e., the Div─Бk─лrti and the restтАЩ (Medh─Бtithi, N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa and Nandana); тАШone who has touched a corpseтАЩ (тАШothersтАЩ in Medh─Бtithi, Govindar─Бja, Kull┼лka and R─Бghav─Бnanda).

This verse is.quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 921), which adds the following:тАФEven though through its proximity to the term тАШ┼ЫavaтАЩ, тАШtatspс╣Ыс╣гс╣нinamтАЩ would appear to mean тАШone who has touched a ┼ЫavaтАЩ, yet inasmuch as the тАШDiv─Бk─лrtiтАЩ and others mentioned before also belong, like the corpse, to the category of тАШunclean thingsтАЩ, it is only right that one who touches the person that has touched all those should bathe. This agrees with Medh─Бtithi.

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 3. 30) to the effect that even when between the man and an unclean thing, there interposes a living thing (like the man who has touched the unclean things) the man has to bathe.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 258) to the effect that the man who touches one who has touched the Div─Бk─лrti and the rest, should bathe; i.e., the touch of an unclean thing defiles also when it is indirect, being interposed by a living object (like the man touching the Div─Бk─лrti &c.).

It is quoted in V─лramitrodaya (─Аhnika, p. 202), which explains Div─Бk─лrti as тАШChaс╣Зс╕Н─БlaтАЩ;тАФand in Vidh─Бnap─Бrij─Бta (p. 54), which reproduces the note made by Madanap─Бrij─Бta is quoted in Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava (─Аc─Бra, p. 257), which explains тАШdiv─Бk─лrtiтАЩ as тАШChaс╣Зс╕Н─БlaтАЩ;тАФin Hem─Бdri (┼Ъr─Бddha, p. 796);тАФin ┼Ъuddhikaumud─л. (p. 327), which explains тАШdiv─Бk─лrtiтАЩ as тАШchaс╣Зс╕Н─БlaтАЩ;тАФin ─Аc─Бramay┼лkha (p. 42);тАФand in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (pp. 159 and 468), which explains тАШtatspс╣Ыс╣гс╣нinтАЩ as тАШone who has touched a dead bodyтАЩ.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Gautama (14.30).тАФтАШOn touching an outcast, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, a woman impure on account of confinement, a woman in her courses, or a corpse,тАФand on touching persons who have touched them,тАФhe shall purify himself by bathing in his clothes.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (1.9.5).тАФтАШOn touching a tree standing on a sacred spot, a funeral pyre, a sacrificial post, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, or a person who sells the Veda,тАФa Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall bathe in his clothes.тАЩ

Baudh─Бyana (1.11.36).тАФтАШOn touching one who sells the Veda, a sacrificial post, an outcast, a funeral pyre, a dog or a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, he shall bathe.тАЩ

Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha (4.37).тАФтАШWhen he has touched a sacrificial post, a pyre, a burial ground, a menstruating woman, a woman lately confined, impure men, or C─Бс╣Зс╕Нalas and so forth,тАФhe shall bathe, submerging both bis body and his head.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (22.69).тАФтАШAfter having touched one who has touched a corpse, or a woman in her courses, or a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla or a sacrificial post,тАФbathing is ordained.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (3.29).тАФтАШOn touching a woman in her courses or persons suffering from impurity due to birth and death, one should bathe; on touching persons who have touched them he shall rinse his mouth.тАЩ

Saс╣Гvarta (Apar─Бrka, p. 921).тАФтАШFor one who touches one who has touched these, bathing has been enjoined.тАЩ

Viс╣гс╣Зu (Do.).тАФтАШOn touching a woman in her courses, a corpse, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, human bone with fat, one should bathe with his clothes on.тАЩ

Chyavana (Do., p. 922).тАФтАШOne shall bathe with clothes on on touching an outcast, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, one who lives upon property belonging to gods, the village-priest, the Soma-vendor, the sacril├мcial post, a funeral pyre, a wood of the pyre, wine, wine-vessel, human bone with fat, one who has touched a corpse, a woman in her courses, one who has committed a heinous crime, or a corpse; after bathing, he should touch fire, repeat the G─Бyatr─л a hundred and eight times, bathe again and then rinse his mouth thrice.тАЩ

Bс╣Ыhaspati (Apar─Бrka, p. 922).тАФтАШAn outcast, a woman lately confined, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla,тАФ on touching these intentionally one becomes purified by bathing with clothes on, touching fire and eating butter. On touching a person who has touched a corpse, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, a funeral pyre, a sacrificial post, a woman in her courses, intentionally, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa shall become purified by bathing.тАЩ

M─Бrkaс╣Зс╕Нeya Pur─Бс╣Зa (Apar─Бrka, p. 923).тАФтАШOne whose food should not be eaten, a woman lately confined, a eunuch, a cat, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, a dog, a cock, an outcast, an excommunicated person, a corpse-carrier, a woman in her courses, a pig,тАФon touching these one becomes purified by bathing.тАЩ

Vс╣Ыddha-Y─Бj├▒avalkya (Do.).тАФтАШOn touching a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, a Pukkasa, a Mleccha, a Bhilla, a P─Бras─лka, one who has committed a heinous crime,тАФone should bathe with clothes on.тАЩ

Par─Б┼Ыara (Do.).тАФтАШOn touching a tree growing in a crematorium, a funeral pyre, a sacrificial post, a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, a Soma-vendor,тАФthe Br─Бhmaс╣Зa should enter water with clothes on.тАЩ

Devala (Do.).тАФтАШA Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, an outcast, a corpse-carrier, a woman lately confined, a woman in her courses,тАФon touching these one becomes purified by bathing.тАЩ

V─Бyupur─Бс╣Зa (Do.).тАФтАШThe woman in her courses, the woman lately confined, the dog, the Anty─Бvas─Бyin, the corpse-carrier,тАФon touching these there is impurity, from which one becomes purified by bathing with clay and with clothes on.тАЩ

Par─Б┼Ыara (Do., p. 926).тАФтАШIf one happens to touch a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla and the corpse and other things after sunset, he becomes purified by touching fire and gold.тАЩ

Aс╣Еgiras (Par─Б┼Ыaram─Бdhava, p. 257).тАФтАШOn touching a person who has touched a corpse, a woman in her courses and a woman lately confined or one outcastтАФone becomes purified on bathing with clothes on.тАЩ

K┼лrmapur─Бс╣Зa (Do., p. 258).тАФтАШIf one touches by chance a person who has been touched by a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, a woman lately confined, or a corpse,тАФhe shall sip water and do japa; if one intentionally touches the said person, he should sip water for the purpose of purifying himself.тАЩ

B├╝hler

085 When he has touched a Kandala, a menstruating woman, an outcast, a woman in childbed, a corpse, or one who has touched a (corpse), he becomes pure by bathing.

086 рдЖрдЪрдореНрдп рдкреНрд░рдпрддреЛ ...{Loading}...

рдЖрдЪрдореНрдп рдкреНрд░рдпрддреЛ рдирд┐рддреНрдпрдВ
рдЬрдкреЗрджреН рдЕрд╢реБрдЪрд┐-рджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗ ред
рд╕реМрд░рд╛рдиреН рдордиреНрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреН рдпрдереЛрддреНрд╕рд╛рд╣рдВ
рдкрд╛рд╡рдорд╛рдиреАрд╢реН рдЪ рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рддрдГ рее рел.реорем рее [реорел рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

On seeing unclean things, the man, after having sipped water, shall always attentively recite the Solar Mantras according to his inclination, as also the P─Бvam─Бn─л verses, according to his capacity.тАФ(85).

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЕрд╢реБрдЪрдпрдГ рд╕рдВрдирд┐рдзрд╛рдирд╛рддреН рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд╛ рдПрд╡ ред рд╕реВрд░реНрдпрджреИрд╡рддреНрдпрд╛ рдордиреНрддреНрд░рд╛рдГ рд╕реМрд░рд╛рдГ “рдЙрджреН рдЙ рддреНрдпрдВ рдЬрд╛рддрд╡реЗрджрд╕рдореН” (рд░реНрд╡реН рез.релреж.рез) рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрдпрдГ ред рдкрд╛рд╡рдорд╛рдгреНрдпрдГ рджрд╛рд╢рддрдпреАрд╖реБ рдирд╡рдореЗ рдордгреНрдбрд▓реЗ рд╜рдзреАрддрд╛рдГ “рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдпрд╛” рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджреНрдпрд╛рдГ (рд░реНрд╡реН реп.рез.рез) ред рдпрдереЛрддреНрд╕рд╛рд╣рдВ рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪ рдПрдХ рдПрд╡рд╛рд░реНрдердГ ред рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╡рд╢рд╛рдЪреН рдЫрдмреНрджрджреНрд╡рдпрдВ рдкрдард┐рддрдореН ред рдмрд╣реБрд╡рдЪрдирдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢рд╛рддреН рддреНрд░рд┐рддреНрд╡рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╢реНрдпрдВ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрд╛ ред рдкрд░рддрд╕реН рддреБ рдпрджрд┐ рдЧреБрд░реБрддрд░рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рддреНрдпрдпреЛ рди рднрд╡рддрд┐ рддрджрд╛ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдп рдПрд╡ рдЬрдкрдГ ред рдордиреНрддреНрд░рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдгрд╛рддреН рдкрд╛рд╡рдорд╛рдиреАрд░реН рдЗрддрд┐ рдЪ рдЛрдЪрд╛рдореН рдЙрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдирд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕рдорд╛рдкреНрддреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕реВрдХреНрддреЗ рддреНрд░рд┐рднреНрдп рдКрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рдВ рднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ рд╢реБрджреНрдзрд┐рдГ ред рд╢реНрд╡рд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рд╕реЛ рд╜рдкреНрдпреН рдЕрд╢реБрдЪрд┐рд░реН рдПрд╡ ред рдкрдард┐рддрдВ рдЪ рдЧреМрддрдореАрдпреЗ рд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдПрд╡ рд╡рд░реНрдЧреЗ- “рд╢реБрдирд╢реН рдЪ ред рдпрджреН рдЙрдкрд╣рдиреНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдПрдХреЗ” рдЗрддрд┐ (рдЧреНрдзреН резрек.рейреитАУрейрей) ред рдкреНрд░рдпрддрдГ рдЕрдирдиреНрдпрдордирд╛ рдордиреНрддреНрд░рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛рджрд┐рдзреНрдпрд╛рдирдкрд░рдГ ред рдЕрде рд╡рд╛ рдкреНрд░рдпрддреЛ рджреЗрд╡рддрд╛рджрд┐рдкреВрдЬрд╛рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддреЛ рдпрджрд╛ рдкрд╢реНрдпреЗрддреН рддрджреИрд╡ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рдиреН рдирд╛рдиреНрдпрджреЗрддрд┐ рее рел.реорел рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШUnclean thingsтАЩ.тАФ Those just mentioned are to be understood as meant here, because of their proximity.

Those mantras that are addressed to the Sun are called тАШSolarтАЩ and the mantras meant are тАШudutyam j─Бtavedasam, &c. &c.тАЩ

The P─Бvam─Бn─л verses.тАФThe verses тАШsv─Бdiс╣гс╣нaye, &c. &c.тАЩ occurring in the ninth maс╣Зс╕Нala of the с╣Ъgveda.

тАШAccording to his inclinationтАЩ and тАШaccording to his capacityтАЩ mean the same thing; two words have been used for the purposes of metre.

In as much as the тАШmantrasтАЩ and тАШversesтАЩ are mentioned in the plural, at least three verses should be recited; and as regards more, they may be recited only if other and more important duties do not suffer thereby. Then again, since the text speaks of тАШmantras and the term тАШP─Бram─Бn─лтАЩ also refers to verses, purification is brought about as soon as one has gone beyond three verses, even though the hymn may not be completed.

The dog also has to be included among the тАШunclean thingsтАЩ; as it also is unclean. In the present context Gautama has declaredтАФтАШOf the dog also; whatever it might pollute, say someтАЩ (14.29-30).

тАШAttentivelyтАЩ;тАФwithout allowing his mind to wander about; he should fix it upon contemplating the deity. Or, тАШPrayataс╕етАЩ may mean that тАШat a time when one is busy with worshipping deities, if he should happen to touch an unclean thing, he should do what is here laid down,тАФand not otherwiseтАЩ.тАФ(85).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(Verse 86 of others.)

Kull┼лka and others take the verse as referring to the case where a man happens to see an unclean thing after having done ─Бcamana (preparatory to some religious act).тАФMedh─Бtithi and Govindar─Бja take it as referring to the case already noted in the foregoing verse,тАФi.e., the meaning being that тАШwhenever one happens to see any of the unclean things just enumerated, he shall do ─Бcamana and then recite the verses prescribed.тАЩ

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 1198);тАФand in Hem─Бdri (┼Ъr─Бddha, p. 796).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Baudh─Бyana (1.15.31).тАФтАШIf he has looked at any unclean substance, he mutters the verseтАФтАЬUnrestrained is the internal organ, wretched the eye-sight, the sun is the chief of the lights; O D─лkс╣г─Б, do not forsake me!тАЭтАЩ

─Аpastamba (Apar─Бrka, p. 1197).тАФтАШOn seeing in the evening a Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla or an outcast, a woman in her courses or unclean things, he should look at the rising sun.тАЩ

Bodh─Бyana (Apar─Бrka, p. 1200).тАФтАШOn seeing the Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, one should look at the stars; on talking to him, one should converse with the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa; on touching him, he shall bathe.тАЩ

B├╝hler

086 He who has purified himself by sipping water shall, on seeing any impure (thing or person), always mutter the sacred texts, addressed to Surya, and the Pavamani (verses).

087 рдирд╛рд░рдВ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛рд╕реНрдерд┐ ...{Loading}...

рдирд╛рд░рдВ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛рд╕реНрдерд┐ рд╕-рд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣рдВ
рд╕реНрдирд╛рддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╡рд┐рдкреНрд░реЛ рд╡рд┐рд╢реБрдзреНрдпрддрд┐ ред
рдЖрдЪрдореНрдпреИрд╡ рддреБ рдирд┐рдГрд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣рдВ,
рдЧрд╛рдореН рдЖрд▓рднреНрдпрд╛ рд╜рд░реНрдХрдореН рдИрдХреНрд╖реНрдп рд╡рд╛ рее рел.реорен рее [реорем рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Having touched a fatty human bone, the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa becomes pure by bathing, but if it be free from fat, then by sipping water and touching a cow, or looking at the sunтАФ(86).

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдирд░реЛ рдордиреБрд╖реНрдпрд╕реН рддрд╕реНрдпреЗрджрдореН рдирд╛рд░рдореН ред рд╕рд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣рдВ рдорд╛рдВрд╕рдордЬреНрдЬрд╛рджрд┐рдЧреНрдзрдореН ред рдЧреЛрд░реН рдЖрд▓рдВрднрдирдВ рд╕реНрдкрд░реНрд╢рдГ ред рдЕрд░реНрдХрджрд░реНрд╢рдирдЧрд╡рд╛рд▓рдореНрдмреМ рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкреНрдпреЗрддреЗ197 рее рел.реорем рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШN─Бra,тАЩ тАШhuman,тАЩтАФbelonging to man.

тАШFattyтАЩтАФi.e. Besmeared with flesh, marrow &c.

тАШ─АlabhyaтАЩ means touching.

The touching of the cow and looking at the sun are meant to be optional alternatives.тАФ(86).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(Verse 87 of others.)

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 924), which notes that what is meant is the combination of all the threeтАФ(1) ─Бcamana, (2) touching of the cow, and (3) looking at the sun; and that this pertains to the case of touching the bone unintentionally; for intentional touching, there is impurity for three days (when fat is adhering to the bone), and one day (when the bone is dry).

It is quoted in Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 3.30), which remarks that this refers to the bone of a twice-born person;тАФin Smс╣Ыtitattva (II, p. 293), which, explains тАШ─БlabhyaтАЩ as тАШhaving touched,тАЩ and adds that this refers to the unintentional touching of the bone;тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 257), which adds that тАШthis refers to twice-born personsтАЩ;тАФin V─лramitrodaya (─Аhnika, p. 214);тАФin Hem─Бdri (┼Ъr─Бddha, p. 796);тАФin ┼Ъuddhikaumud─л, (p. 329), which explains тАШ─БlabhyaтАЩ as тАШhaving touchedтАЩ;тАФin Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhapras─Бda (─Аhnika, p. 16b);тАФand in Pr─Бya┼Ыcittaviveka (p. 485), which says that this refers to cases of unintentional touching

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (Apar─Бrka, p. 925).тАФтАШOn touching a fatty human bone, there is impurity lasting for three days; when it is not fatty, for one day and night.тАЩ

Devala (Do.).тАФтАШHuman bone, human fat, ordure, menstrual blood, wine, semen, marrow, blood,тАФon touching these one should bathe.тАЩ

ChyavanaтАФ(See under 84.)

Saс╣Гvarta (Viramitrodaya-─Аhnika, p. 214)тАФтАШIndigo, indigo-products, human bone, or the shadow cast by the Caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla and the outcast,тАФon touching these, the twice-born person shall bathe.тАЩ

B├╝hler

087 A Brahmana who has touched a human bone to which fat adheres, becomes pure by bathing; if it be free from fat, by sipping water and by touching (afterwards) a cow or looking at the sun.

088 рдЖрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯреА рдиреЛрджрдХрдореН ...{Loading}...

рдЖрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯреА+++(=рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдпрдГ)+++ +++(рддрд░реНрдкрдгреЗрди)+++ рдиреЛрджрдХрдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН
рдЖ рд╡реНрд░рддрд╕реНрдп рд╕рдорд╛рдкрдирд╛рддреН ред
рд╕рдорд╛рдкреНрддреЗ рддреВрджрдХрдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛
рддреНрд░рд┐рд░рд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдгреИрд╡ рд╢реБрдзреНрдпрддрд┐ рее рел.реорео рее [реорен рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The person under instruction shall not make water-offerings till the completion of his pupilage; at its completion, he becomes pure in three days, after having made the water-offerings.

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЖрджреЗрд╢ рдЖрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдореН ред рд╡реНрд░рддрд╛рджреЗрд╢рдирд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд╛рджреН рд░реВрдврд┐рд░реВрдкреЗрдг рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордЪрд╛рд░реНрдпреН рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрд╕реНрдп рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордЪрд░реНрдпрд╛рд╢реНрд░рдорд╕реНрдерд╕реНрдп рд╕рддреЛ рдпреЗ рд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рдореАрдпрдиреНрддреЗ рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдпрдореН рдЕрдирд┐рд╖реНрдЯреЛрджрдХрджрд╛рдирдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ198 ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рдХреНрдкреНрд░рдореАрддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рддреБ рд╡рд┐рд╣рд┐рддрдореН рдЕрдиреНрд╡рд╛рд╣рд┐рдХрдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рджреЗрд╡рдкрд┐рддреГрддрд░реНрдкрдгрдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЖ рд╡реНрд░рддрд╕реНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рдЖ рд╕рдорд╛рд╡рд░реНрддрдирд╛рджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рди рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЖрдиреНрддрд░рд╛рд▓рд┐рдХрд╕рд╛рд╣рд╕рд┐рдХрд╛рджреН рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд░реНрдердГ ред рд╡реНрд░рддрдЪрд░рдгрд╕рдорд╛рдкреНрддреЗрдГ рд╕рдорд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрдГ рд╕ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдПрдХреИрдХрд╕реНрдпреЛрджрдХрдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡реИрдХрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрд╣рдирд┐, рддреНрд░рд┐рд░рд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдЖрд╢реМрдЪрдВ рдХреБрд░реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдорд╛рддреБрд╕реН рддреВрджрдХрджрд╛рдирдВ рд╡реНрд░рддрд┐рдиреЛ рд╜рдкреАрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ ред рди рдЪ рд╡реНрд░рддрд▓реЛрдкрдГ ред рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░рдореН рдЙрджрд╛рд╣рд░рдиреНрддрд┐- рдЕрдкрд░рд╛рдзреНрдп рдЖрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯреА рдиреЛрджрдХ рдЗрддрд┐ рее рел.реорен рее

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

тАШ─Аdiс╣гс╣нaтАЩ means тАШ─Бde┼ЫaтАЩ, тАШinstructionтАЩ; and the term тАШperson under instructionтАЩ denotes the Student, by reason of his connection with the instruction that he receives regarding his observances. The present text prohibits the making of water-offerings by one who is still in the state of the Student, to such Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa relations as may happen to die during that period. As for those that have died before, the offering of water to the forefathers and Gods has already been prescribed for the Student also.

тАШTill the completion of his pupilage;тАФi.e. till the performance of the тАШSam─БvartanaтАЩ ceremony; and it does not mean any forced completion of the stage in the interval.

On returning after having finished his observances, he shall make a water-offering to each of the dead relations on one day; and he should observe тАШimpurityтАЩ for three days.

As regards the making of water-offering to his mother, this is necessary for the Student also; and such an offering does not interfere with the proper fulfilment of his observances. In support of this they quote another Smс╣Ыti -textтАФviz. тАШThe person undergoing instruction does not commit a wrong in making a water-offering.тАЩтАФ(87).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(Verse 88 of others).

This rule does not apply to the case of the mother (Medh─Бtithi),тАФfather and mother (Govindar─Бja),тАФfather, mother and ─Бc─Бrya (Kulluka).

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 876), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШ─Бdiс╣гс╣н─лтАЩ is the тАШReligious Student,тАЩтАФтАШ─Бvratasya sam─Бpan─БtтАЩ means тАШtill the Sam─Бvartana ceremony has been performedтАЩ;тАФin Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б (on 3.5) which adds that the Religious Student is called тАШ─Бdiс╣гс╣н─лтАЩ by reason of his receiving such ─Бdiс╣гс╣нa, ─Бde┼Ыa, injunction, as тАШThou art a Religious Student, drink water, do your dutyтАЩ and so forth;тАФthat this refers to the death of persons other than the Father and others.

It is quoted in Madanap─Бrij─Бta, (p. 405) as pertaining to cases other than the death of the тАШmother and othersтАФit explains тАШ─Бdiс╣гс╣н─лтАЩ as тАШReligious Student,тАЩ but adds that some people explain the term as тАШone who is undergoing expiatory penance.тАЩ The second half means that on the expiration of the тАШvrata,тАЩ he shall make the water-offering and remain impure for three days.

It is quoted in Nirс╣Зayansindhu (pp. 195 and 392) to the effect that after the Sam─Бvartana ceremony has been performed, the Religious Student shall observe an тАШimpurityтАЩ for three days, for the death of persons that may have occurred during his studentship;тАФin Gad─Бdharapaddhati (K─Бla, p. 313), which explains тАШ─Бdiс╣гс╣н─лтАЩ as the Religious Student;тАФin H─Бralat─Б (p. 201), which has the following note:тАФтАШ─Бdiс╣гс╣нaтАЩ stands for the observances prescribed in connection with Vedic study, and тАШ─Бdiс╣гс╣н─лтАЩ stands for the Religious Student, as also for other persons that may be keeping certain observances; so long as the course of the observance has not been finished, the man should not offer

the death-oblations even to his Preceptor;тАФin Saс╣Гsk─Бraratnam─Бl─Б, (p. 295), which says that Mit─Бkс╣гar─Б has explained тАШ─Бdiс╣гс╣н─лтАЩ as the Religious Student;тАФand in Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 216).

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

Viс╣гс╣Зu (22.87).тАФ(Same as Manu.)

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (3.5).тАФтАШThe religious student shall not make water-offerings.тАЩ

B├╝hler

088 He who has undertaken the performance of a vow shall not pour out libations (to the dead) until the vow has been completed; but when he has offered water after its completion, he becomes pure in three days only.

рдЕрдирд╛рд╢реМрдЪрдореН

089 рд╡реГрдерд╛-рд╕рдЩреНрдХрд░-рдЬрд╛рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдкреНрд░рд╡реНрд░рдЬреНрдпрд╛рд╕реБ ...{Loading}...

рд╡реГрдерд╛-рд╕рдЩреНрдХрд░-рдЬрд╛рддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ,
+++(рд╕рдиреНрдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рджрд┐рд╖реБ)+++ рдкреНрд░рд╡реНрд░рдЬреНрдпрд╛рд╕реБ +++(рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕реБ)+++ рдЪ рддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддрд╛рдореН ред
рдЖрддреНрдордирд╕реН рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрд┐рдирд╛рдВ рдЪреИрд╡
рдирд┐рд╡рд░реНрддреЗрддреЛрджрдХрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ рее рел.реореп рее [реорео рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The water-offering is withdrawn from those born in vain and from intermixture, from those who are addicted to asceticism and from those who have abandoned themselves.тАФ(88)

(A) Well, Gautama (14.12) has saidтАФтАШIn the case of those dying from hunger, by a weapon, by fire, by poison, in water, in prison, or from a precipice,тАФit is only when it is unintentional.тАЩ While in the verse just quoted it is said simply, without any qualification тАШThose dying at the hands of the C─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla &c.тАЩ And on account of the necessity of reconciling this with what has been said in the other Smс╣Ыti text regarding the case of тАШdying in waterтАЩ &c., it must be тАШintentional deathтАЩ that is meant. And the idea arises that by reason of тАШassociation,тАЩ the same should be the case with the others also.

(B) On the other hand, the verse quoted uses the term тАШsinfulтАЩ; and all sinful act has been prohibited; he who does what is prohibited is called тАШsinfulтАЩ. And a man becomes the тАШdoerтАЩ of an act through his own initiative, as also through the urging of another person. Now, death тАШfrom lightning, and the fanged and horned animalsтАЩ could never belong to the former category (i.e. this could never be intentional); and no one is ever urged by others to such death; nor are these means of dying employed by suicides, as holes, water and sword etc., are, and it is only if these were so, and the man were to kill himself by having recourse to these, that he could be the тАШself-sufficient agett (agent?),тАЩ of the act of тАШdying.тАЩ The truth therefore is that the man who comes by such death is understood to have been sinful in his previous life,тАФas is learnt from the scriptures; just as the possession of тАШblack teethтАЩ and the rest. If it be askedтАФтАШwhat is the use of this fact of the manтАЩs having been sinful in the past being indicated?тАЩ But in the case of persons with deficient limbs etc.,; their previous connection with sin is clearly indicated; and the expiatory rite to be performed in the case has been laid down by Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha, as consisting, in the case of some men, of the performance of two Kс╣Ыcchras, and in that of others, of something more.

(C) In reality however, the suicide having died, can have nothing to do with the performance of any rites. Or, if he be regarded as having commited a grievous sin, then, any person who may have entered into any kind of relationship with himтАФmarital, or friendly, or sacrificial,тАФwould also have to be regarded as sinful. But such is not the usage of cultured men. For as a matter of fact, people having relationship with suicides are not looked down upon in any way; nor do they perform any expiatory rites.

(D) Some people, having read, in another Smс╣Ыti text, the wordsтАФтАШthose killed by cows and Br─Бhmaс╣Зas etc.тАЩтАФread the words тАШthose who have abandoned themselvesтАЩ apart by themselves, and seem to take up an entirely different position.

The right view is that intentional suicides are what are meant;тАФwhy?тАФbecause of their being spoken of as тАШsinful.тАЩ The man who intentionally proceeds to set into activity the causes leading to his own death, wilfully disobeys the law that тАШno man shall by his own desire, cut off his life-span and it is only right that such a transgressor should be spoken of as тАШsinful.тАЩ

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рдЬрд╛рддрд╢рдмреНрджрдГ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдХреЗрдореН рдЕрднрд┐рд╕рдВрдмрдзреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╡реГрдердЬрд╛рддреЛ рдпреЛ рди рджреЗрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдЕрд░реНрдЪрдпрддрд┐ рди рдкрд┐рддреДрдиреН рди рдордиреБрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реЗ рд╜рдирд╛рд╢реНрд░рдореА, рд╣реБрддрд╛рд╣реБрддрдкрд░рд┐рддреНрдпрдХреНрддрдГ, “рд╕рдВрд╡рддреНрд╕рд░рдореН рдЕрдирд╛рд╢реНрд░рдореА рднреВрддреНрд╡рд╛” рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐ рдЪрд┐рд░рдХрд╛рд▓рд╛рд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛рдиреЗ рдорд╣рд╛рджреЛрд╖рд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгрд╛рддреН ред рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордЪрд╛рд░рд┐рдкрд░рд┐рд╡реНрд░рд╛рдЬрдХрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рдкрд░рдкрд╛рдХрд░рддрд┐рддреНрд╡рдореН ред рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реН рддреБ рдкрд╛рдХреЛ рдирд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзрдГ ред рд╕рдВрдХрд░рдЬрд╛рддрд╛ рдЗрддрд░реЗрддрд░рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рдХрд░реЗрдг рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд▓реЛрдорд╛ рдЖрдпреЛрдЧрд╡рд╛рджрдпрдГ ред рдирд┐рдиреНрджрд┐рддрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рд╡реГрдерд╛рдЬрд╛рддрд╕рд╛рд╣рдЪрд░реНрдпреЗрдг ред рдЕрдиреБрд▓реЛрдорд╛рд╕реН рддреБ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕рдВрдХреАрд░реНрдгрдпреЛрдирд┐рддреНрд╡реЗ рдорд╛рддреГрдЬрд╛рддреАрдпрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛рдЪреН рдЪ рдиреЗрд╣ рдЧреГрд╣реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рди рдЪрд╛рдиреБрд▓реЛрдореЗрд╖реБ рд╕рдВрдХреАрд░реНрдгрдпреЛрдирд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░рдГ ред “рд╕рдВрдХреАрд░реНрдгрдпреЛрдирдпрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдПрддрд╛рдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд▓реЛрдорд╛рдиреБрд▓реЛрдордЬрд╛рдГ” (рдореНрдзреН резреж.реирел) рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдирд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛ рд╕реБрддрд╛рджрдпрдпрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдиреЗрдХрдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕рдВрд╕рд░реНрдЧрдЬрд╛рдГ, рд╡реЗрд╢реНрдпрд╛рдЬрд╛рддрд╛рд╢реН рдЪ ред рдкрд╛рд░рд╕реНрддреНрд░реИрдгреЗрдпрд╛рд╕реН рддреБ рдЕрд╕рддреНрдпрдиреЗрдХрдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕рдВрд╕рд░реНрдЧреЗрдг рд╕рдВрдХрд░рдЬрд╛рддрд╛рдГ ред

  • рдЕрдпрдВ рдЪ рд╕рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ, рди рддрддреНрдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ рдХреЗрдЪрд┐рддреН ред рдЖрддреНрдорддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрд┐рдирд╛рдВ рддреБ рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред

  • рддрджреН рдЕрдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН199 рдЕрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгрд╛рддреН ред

  • рдкреНрд░рд╡реНрд░рдЬреНрдпрд╛рд╕реБ рдмрд╛рд╣реНрдпрд╛рд╕реБ рднрдЧрд╛рд▓рд╡рд░рдХреНрддрдкрдЯрд╛рджреНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрд╡реН рдЕрдирдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд╛рджреН рдмрд╣реБрд╡рдЪрдирдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢рд╛рддреН,200 рд╡реНрд░рддрд╛рджрд┐рджрд░реНрд╢рдирднреЗрджреЗрди рдмрд╛рд╣реНрдпрд╛рдГ ред рдЖрддреНрдордирд╕реН рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрд┐рдирд╛рдВ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЖрдпреБрд╖реЛ рд╜рдХреНрд╖рдпреЗ рд╕реНрд╡реЗрдЪреНрдЫрдпрд╛ рд╢рд░реАрд░рдВ рддреНрдпрдЬрдиреНрддрд┐ ред рд╡реГрджреНрдзрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЕрдЪрд┐рдХрд┐рддреНрд╕реНрдпрдорд╣рд╛рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзреАрдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рднрд┐рд╖рдХреНрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдЦрд╛рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЗрд╖реНрдпрдд рдПрд╡ ред рдпрдереЛрдХреНрддрдореН ред

  • рд╡реГрджреНрдзрдГ рд╢реМрдЪрд╕реНрдореГрддреЗрд░реН рд▓реБрдкреНрддрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрднрд┐рд╖рдХреНрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдГ ред

  • рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирдВ рдШрд╛рддрдпреЗрджреН рдпрд╕реН рддреБ рднреГрдЧреНрд╡рдЧреНрдиреНрдпрдирд╢рдирд╛рдореНрдмреБрднрд┐рдГ рее

  • рддрд╕реНрдп рддреНрд░рд┐рд░рд╛рддреНрд░рдореН рдЖрд╢реМрдЪрдВ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпреЗ рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрд╕реНрддрд┐рд╕рдВрдЪрдпрдГ ред

  • рддреГрддреАрдпреЗ рддреВрджрдХрдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрдереЗ рд╢реНрд░рд╛рджреНрдзрдореН рдЖрдЪрд░реЗрддреН рее рдЗрддрд┐ ред

рдХреБрд╖реНрдЯреНрдпрд╛рджреЗрд╕реН рддреБ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрд╕реНрдп рдЗрд╖реНрдпрдд рдПрд╡ ред рдпрдереЛрдХреНрддрдВ “рд▓реБрдкреНрддрдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯрд╕реНрдп” ред рдЧреГрд╣рд╕реНрдерд╛рд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛рдпрд╛рдореН рдЕрдкрд┐,

  • рдорд╣рд╛рдкреНрд░рд╕реНрдерд╛рдирдЧрдордирд╛ рд╡реГрдерд╛ рдиреЗрдЪреНрдЫрдиреНрддрд┐ рдЬреАрд╡рд┐рддреБрдореН ред

рд▓реБрдкреНрддрдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯрд╢реН рдЪреЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рдпрдГ рд╢реМрдЪрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрд╕рдорд░реНрдердГ рд╕рдВрдзреНрдпреЛрдкрд╛рд╕рдирд╛рджрд┐рд╖реБ рдЪ ред “рдЕрдкрд░рд┐рдХреНрд╖реАрдгрд╢рд░реАрд░реЛ рд╡рд╛ рд╕рд╛рджрдпреЗрджреН рдпрд╕реН рддреНрд╡реН рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирдореН рдЕрд▓реБрдкреНрддрдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯреЛ рд╡рд╛” ред рдЕрддрд╕реН рддрджреНрд╡рд┐рдкрд░реАрддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗрд╖реНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЙрджрдХрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЛ рд╡рд┐рд╣рд┐рддрдГ ред рдпрдереЛрдХреНрддрдореН ред

  • рд░рд╛рдЬрднрд┐рд░реН рдирд┐рд╣рддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рд╢реГрдЩреНрдЧрд┐рджрдВрд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рд┐рд╕рд░реАрд╕реГрдкреИрдГ ред

  • рдЖрддреНрдордирд╕реН рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрд┐рдирд╛рдВ рдЪреИрд╡ рд╢реНрд░рд╛рджреНрдзрдореН рдПрд╖рд╛рдВ рди рдХрд▓реНрдкрдпреЗрддреН рее

  • рдЙрджрдХрдВ рдкрд┐рдгреНрдбрджрд╛рдирдВ рдЪ рдкреНрд░реЗрддреЗрднреНрдпреЛ рдпрдЪреН рдЪ рджреАрдпрддреЗ ред

  • рдиреЛрдкрддрд┐рд╖реНрдардиреНрддрд┐ рддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдореН рдЕрдиреНрддрд░рд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗ рд╡рд┐рдирд╢реНрдпрддрд┐ рее

  • рдирд╛рд░рд╛рдпрдгрдмрд▓рд┐рдГ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпреЛ рд▓реЛрдХрдЧрд░реНрд╣рд╛рднрдпрд╛рдиреН рдирд░реИрдГ ред

  • рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдПрднреНрдпреЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рджрд╛рддрд╡реНрдпрдореН рдЕрдиреНрдирдореН рдПрд╡ рд╕рджрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгрдореН рее

рддрдерд╛рдиреНрдпрддреНрд░ ред

  • рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рд╛рджреН рдЙрджрдХрд╛рддреН рд╕рд░реНрдкрд╛рджреН рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджреН рд╡реИрджреНрдпреБрддрд╛рджреН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред

  • рджрдВрд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рд┐рднреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рдкрд╢реБрднреНрдпрд╢реН рдЪ рдорд░рдгрдореН рдкрд╛рдХрдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛рдореН рее

рддрдерд╛ рдЪреЛрдХреНрддрдореН ред

  • рдиреГрдгрд╛рдВ рдЪреИрд╡рд╛рдЧреНрдирд┐рджрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рд╕реНрдирд╛рдирд╛рд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд╛рдореН ред

  • рддрдкреНрддрдХреГрдЪреНрдЫреНрд░рджреНрд╡рдпреЗ рд╢реБрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реН рдЕрд╢реНрд░реБрдкрд╛рддреЗ рд╜рдиреБрдпрд╛рдпрд┐рдирд╛рдореН рее

  • рддреЗрдиреЛрджреНрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдВ рди рдЪреИрд╡рдиреНрдпреИрдГ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдореН рдЕрд╕реНрдпреМрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рджреЗрд╣рд┐рдХрдореН ред

  • рди рдЪ рдирд╛рдорд╛рдкрд┐ рдХрд░реНрддрд╡реНрдпрдВ рддрджреНрд╡рдВрд╢рд╕реНрдп рддрджреАрдпрдХрдореН рее

  • рдЕрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрдирд░рдХрд╕реНрдерд╕реНрдп рддрд╕реНрдп рдкрд╛рдкреАрдпрд╕реЛ рд╜рдзрд┐рдХрдореН ред

  • рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдВ рдХреАрд░реНрддрдирдВ рдирд╛рдо рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдЪреИрд╡ рднрдпрд╛рд╡рд╣рдореН рее

  • рд╕рдВрд╡рд░реНрддреЗрди рдЖрд╕реНрд╡реН рдПрд╡ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕реБ рд╕рд╛рдиреНрддрдкрдирдореН рдЖрдореНрдирд╛рддрдореН, рдкрд░рд╛рд╢рд░реЗрдг рддрдкреНрддрдХреГрдЪреНрдЫреНрд░рдореН, рд╡рд╕рд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрди рддрдкреНрддрдХреГрдЪреНрдЫрд░рд╕рд╣рд┐рддрдВ рдЪрд╛рдиреНрджреНрд░рд╛рдпрдгрдореН ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╛рджрд┐рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛ рдЙрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдГ ред

  • рдпрджреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН “рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рджреН рдЙрджрдХрд╛рддреН” рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджреНрдпреН рдЙрдкрдХреНрд░рдореНрдп “рдорд░рдгрдВ рдкрд╛рдкрдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛рдореН” рдЗрддрд┐, рддрддреНрд░реЗрджрдВ рд╕рдВрджрд┐рд╣реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рдпрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рджрд┐рд░реН рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдореН рдЖрддреНрдорд╛рдирдВ рдШрд╛рддрдпрддрд┐ рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдпрдВ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд░реН рдФрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рджреЗрд╣рд┐рдХрд╛рдХрд░рдгрдореН, рддрддреНрдХрд░рдгреЗ рдЪ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН, рдЙрдд рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рджрд╣рд╕реНрддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдирд┐рдЪреНрдЫрдд рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдХреБрддрдГ рд╕рдВрджреЗрд╣рдГ ред рдЗрд╣ рдЧреМрддрдореЗрди “рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╛рдирд╛рд╢рдХрд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рдЧреНрдирд┐рд╡рд┐рд╖реЛрджрдХреЛрджреНрдмрдиреНрдзрдирдкреНрд░рдкрддрдиреИрд╢реН рдЪреЗрдЪреНрдЫрддрд╛рдореН201” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдХреНрддрдореН (рдЧреНрдзреН резрек.резреи) ред рдЗрд╣ рдЪрд╛рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗрдг рд╢реНрд░реБрддрдореН “рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рд╛рджреН рдЙрджрдХрд╛рддреН” рдЗрддрд┐ ред рддрддреНрд░ рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗрдгреИрдХрд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН “рдЙрджрдХрд╛рджреН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рддрд╛рд╡рджреН рдЕрд╡рд╢реНрдпрдореН “рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрддрд╛рдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рдВрдмрдзреНрдпрддреЗ ред рд╕рд╛рд╣рдЪрд░реНрдпрд╛рджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рддрдереИрд╡реЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрд╢рдЩреНрдХрд╛ рдЬрд╛рдпрддреЗ ред рдХрд┐рдВ рдЪ “рдкрд╛рдкрдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛рдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢реНрд░реВрдпрддреЗ ред рдкрд╛рдкрдВ рдЪ рдХрд░реНрдо рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзрдореН ред рдЕрддреНрд░ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзрдВ рдпреЛ рд╜рдиреБрддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддрд┐ рд╕ рдкрд╛рдкрдХрд░реНрдореЗрддреНрдпреН рдЙрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдЕрдиреБрд╖реНрдард╛рддреГрддреНрд╡рдВ рдЪ рд╕реНрд╡рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрд╛рд░реЗрдг рдкрд░рдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдХреНрддреГрддрдпрд╛ рдЪ ред рддрддреНрд░ рди рд╡реИрджреНрдпреБрддрджрдВрд╖реНрдЯреНрд░рд┐рд╢реГрдЩреНрдЧреНрдпрд╛рджрдпрдГ ред рддреЗ рдЪ рди рдкреНрд░рдпреБрдЬреНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдирд╛рдкрд┐ рддреЗ рд╢реНрд╡рднреНрд░реЛрджрдХрдЦрдбреНрдЧрд╛рджрд┐рд╕реНрдерд╛рдиреАрдпрд╛рдГ ред рдпреЗрди рддрджреБрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдиреЗрдирд╛рддреНрдорд╛рдирдВ рдШреНрдирдиреН рд╕реНрд╡рддрдиреНрддреНрд░рдГ рдХрд░реНрддрд╛ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рдпрд╕реНрдпреЗрджреГрд╢рдВ рдорд░рдгрдореН рдЙрдкрдирддрдВ рд╕ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдЬрдиреНрдордирд┐ рдХреГрддрдкрд╛рдкрдХ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░реЗрдг рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрдерд╛ рд╢реНрдпрд╛рд╡рджрдиреНрддрдкреНрд░рднреГрддрдпрдГ ред рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдкрд┐ рдХрд┐рдореН рдПрддреЗрди рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрд┐рддреЗрди ред рдЕрдЩреНрдЧрд╣реАрдирд╛рджреАрдирд╛рдВ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рдкрд╛рдкрд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐рддреНрд╡рдВ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдореН рдЕрдиреБрд╖реНрдареЗрдпрдВ рдпрдерд╛ рд╡рд╕рд┐рд╖реНрдареЗрдиреЛрдХреНрддрдореН ред рдХрд╕реНрдпрдЪрд┐рддреН рдХреГрдЪреНрдЫреНрд░рджреНрд╡рдпрдЪрд░рдгрдВ рдХрд╕реНрдпрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрднреНрдпрдзрд┐рдХрдореН рдЕрдкрд┐ ред рдЗрд╣ рдореГрддреНрдпреБрдирд╛ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд╣реГрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдирд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рд╜рдиреЗрди ред рдпрджрд┐ рд╡рд╛рд╕реМ рдХреГрддрдкрд╛рддрдХ рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рд╕реАрдпрддреЗ ред рддреЗрди рд╕рд╣ рдпреЗрди рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рддреН202 рдпреМрдирдореМрдЦрд╕реНрд░реМрд╡рд╛рдГ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд╛рдГ рдХреГрддрд╛рдГ рд╕реЛ рд╜рдкрд┐ рдкрд╛рдкрдХрд╛рд░реА рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН ред рди рдЪреИрд╡рдВ рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдирд╛рдореН рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░рдГ ред рди рд╣рд┐ рддрд╛рджреГрд╢реЗрди рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдВ рдХреГрддрд╡рдиреНрддрдГ рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рджреН рд╡рд┐рдЪрд┐рдХрд┐рддреНрд╕реНрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддрдВ рдирд╛рдЪрд░рдиреНрддрд┐ ред рдЕрдд рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрддрд╛рдореН рдЕрдиреБрдореАрдпрддреЗ ред

  • рдпреЗ рддреБ “рдЧреЛрдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╣рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗ рдкрдард┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ “рдЖрддреНрдордирд╕реН рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрд┐рдирд╛рдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреГрдердХреН рдкрдардиреНрддрд┐ рддреЗрди рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдкрдХреНрд╖рдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рднрд╛рддрд┐ ред

  • рдЕрддрдГ рд╕рдВрд╢рдпрдГ рдХрд┐рдВ рдкреБрдирд░реН рдЕрддреНрд░ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН ред

  • рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрддрд╛рдореН рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдХреБрддрдГ ред рдкрд╛рдкрдХрд░реНрдорд╡рдЪрдирд╛рддреН ред рд╕реНрд╡реЗрдЪреНрдЫрдпрд╛ рдпрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рддреНрдорд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐рд╣реЗрддреМ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрд╛рд░реЗ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ рддреЗрди “рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЙ рд╣ рди рдкреБрд░рд╛рдпреБрд╖рдГ рд╕реНрд╡рдГ рдХрд╛рдореА рдкреНрд░реЗрдпрд╛рддреН” (рд╢реНрдмреН резреж.реи.рем.рен) рдЗрддрд┐ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдореН рдЕрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрдВ рднрд╡рддрд┐ ред рд╕ рдЪ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдГ рдкрд╛рдкрдХрд░реНрдореЗрддрд┐ рд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╖реНрдЯреБрдореН ред

  • рдирдиреБ рдЪреЛрдХреНрддрдВ рди рд╣рд┐ рддреЗ рдЦрдбреНрдЧрд╛рджрд┐рд╕реНрдерд╛рдиреАрдпрд╛рдГ, рдпреЗрдиреЗрдЪреНрдЫрдпрд╛ рд╡рдзреЛрдкрдкрддреНрддрд┐рдГ ред

  • рдЙрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрдГ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рджрдВ рди рд░рдХреНрд╖рддрд┐ рддреЗрди рддрддреН рдХреГрддрдореН рдПрд╡реЗрддрд┐ ред рддреЗрди рдпрд╢реН рдЪрд╛рдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рджрд╕реНрдпреБрднреВрдпрд┐рд╖реНрдареЗ рд╜рд░рдгреНрдп рдПрдХрд╛рдХреА рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐, рддрд╕реНрдп рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рд╛ рдорд╛рдВ рдШреНрдирдиреНрддреНрд╡реН рдЗрддреАрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ рди рднрд╡рддрд┐, рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рддрддреНрд╕рдорд░реНрдерд╛рдЪрд░реЗрдгреЗрди рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рджрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд░рд┐рд╣реГрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рднрд╡рддреНрдпреН рдПрд╡ рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдордГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдпреЛ рдмрд╛рд╣реБрднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдирджреАрдВ рддрд░рддрд┐ рд╕рдВрджрд┐рдЧреНрдзрд╛рдВ рд╡рд╛ рдирд╛рд╡рдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рд░реЛрд╣рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдХреБрд╢рд▓рдХрд░реНрдгрдзрд╛рд░рд╛рдзрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рддрд╛рдореН, рдПрд╡рдВ рддрд╕реНрдп рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрджреНрдпрдорд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рд╡реЗрдЧрдХреНрд╖рдпреЗрдг рдиреМрдкрд░рд┐рд╡рд░реНрддрдирд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд╛ рдпреБрдХреНрддреИрд╡ рдкрд╛рдкрдХрд╛рд░рд┐рддрд╛ ред рддрдерд╛ рдЪрд╛рдЧрд╛рдзрддрд╛рдВ рджрдгреНрдбрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╣рдордХрд░рд╕рдВрдЧрдВ рдЪрд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рддреНрд╡рд╛203 рд╕реНрдирд╛рддрд╛рд░реЛ рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд╣реНрд░рд┐рдпреЗрд░рдиреН рди рджреБрд╖реНрдпреЗрдпреБрдГ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рдпрд╕реН рддреБ рджреГрдврдмрдиреНрдзрдирд╛рдВ рддрдиреНрд╡рд░рд┐рддреНрд░рд╛рдВ рддрд░рд┐рдВ рддреАрд╡реНрд░рд╛рдореНрднрд╕рд┐ рдХреБрд╢рд▓рд╛рд╡рд╣рд┐рддрд╕рдорд░реНрдердкреНрд░реЗрд░рдХрдкреНрд░реЗрд░реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрд╛рдореН рдЕрдзрд┐рд░реВрдврдГ рд╕рд╣рд╕реЛрддреНрдкрддрд┐рддреЗ рдЬрд╡рд┐рдирд┐ рдкрд╡рдиреЗ рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╡рд╛рддреЗрди рдкрд┐рдЪреНрдЫрд▓рдореН рдЕрд╡рд╛рдкреНрддрд╡рд╛рдиреН рдкреНрд▓рд╡рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рдореНрд░рд┐рдпреЗрдд рди204 рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдореН рдЕрддрд┐рдХреНрд░рдореЗрддреН ред рдПрд╡рдВ рд╕рд░реНрдкреЛрдкрд╣рддрдВ рджреЗрд╢рдВ рдЪ рдЕрдкрд░рд┐рд╣рд░рдиреН рджрд╖реНрдЯреЛ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрджреНрдпреЗрдд рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрд╡реЗрдпрд╛рджреН рдПрд╡, рдирд╛рдиреНрдпрдерд╛ ред рдПрд╡рдВ рддреАрдХреНрд╖реНрдгрд╢реГрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдВ рдЧрд╛рдВ рд╣рд╕реНрддрд┐рдирдВ рд╡рд╛ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛ рджреВрд░рдореН рдЕрдирдкрдХреНрд░рд╛рдорддреЛ рд╣рдиреНрдпрдорд╛рдирд╕реНрдп рдпреБрдХреНрддреЛ рд╜рддреНрд░рд┐рдХреНрд░рдордГ ред рдПрд╡рдореН рдЕрд░рдгреНрдпреЗ рд╡рд░реНрд╖рд╛рд╕реВрдЪреНрдЪрд░рдиреНрддреАрд╖реБ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпреБрддреНрд╕реБ рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдордирдЧрд░реНрдпреЛрд░реН рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╡реЗрд╢реЗ рджреБрд╖реНрдЯрддреИрд╡ ред рдЧреНрд░рд╛рдорд╕реНрдерд╕реНрдпреЛрдкрд░рд┐ рдХрдердВрдЪрд┐рджреН рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпреБрддреНрдкрд╛рддрдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреН рддрджрд╛ рди рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдкрд░рд╛рдзреНрдпрддрд┐ ред рдЕрддреЛ рдпреБрдХреНрддрдореН рдЗрджреГрд╢рдВ рдпрдерд╛рд╡рд┐рд╣рд┐рддрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдХрд░рдгрдореН ред

  • рддрддреНрд░ рдЪреЛрджрдХрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реМрд░реНрдзреНрд╡рджреЗрд╣рд┐рдХрдкреНрд░рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд░реНрдердГ, рд╕реНрдореГрддреНрдпрдиреНрддрд░реЗ рд╜рд╕реНрдпреЛрджрд╛рд╣реГрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рее рел.реорео рее
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рднрд╛рд╖реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

The term тАШbornтАЩ is to be construed separately with each of the two terms with which it is compounded. He is said to be ^(тАШ)born in vainтАЩ who does not worship Gods, Pitс╣Ыs or Men; i. e. he who does not lead the life proper for uny of the four stages of life, even though he is capable of doing so; one who is excluded from all offerings and invitations. Having referred to the man тАШwho for one year does not lead the life proper for any stage,тАЩ the scriptures speak of a great sin attaching to persons doing this for any length of time. This is so because with the exception of the Student and the Renunciate, all the others have to cook food for other people; and it is only cooking for oneтАЩs own self alone that has been prohibited.

тАШBorn of intermixture;тАЩтАФi.e., the ─АyogaraтАЩ and other persons born of an improper and inverse mixture of the several castes; that the issue of improper mixtures is meant is indicated by its association with those тАШborn in vain,тАЩ which implies lowness of birth. As regards the issue of legal mixtures, even though these also are тАШborn of intermixtures,тАЩ yet these are not meant here, because they belong definitely to their motherтАЩs caste and are entitled to all that pertains thereto. Further, in ordinary usage children of legal mixtures are not spoken of as being of тАШmixed originтАЩ; e.g. in 10.25, where the issues of тАШmixed originтАЩ are described. The term also includes (a) the children of such widows as have not been тАШpermittedтАЩ to beget children, born of the intercourse of several men, and (b) the children of prostitutes; the children of women begotten by a person other than their husbands are not included in this category, if there has not been intercourse with several men.

Some people hold that this prohibition refers to Sapiс╣Зс╕Нa relations who are as described, and not to their sons; while in the case of those who have тАШabandoned themselves,тАЩ it applies to their sons also.

This however is not right; as the text makes no distinction among those mentioned.

Asceticisms; i.e., of heretics, such as the тАШBhagala,тАЩ the тАШRaktapaс╣нaтАЩ and the rest. That these are meant is indicated by the plural number and by the fact that it is the heterodox heretic alone that is excluded. These are regarded as тАШheterodoxтАЩ by reason of their observances &c., being different from those of the orthodox ascetics.

тАШThose who have abandoned themselves;тАЩтАФi.e ., those who, even before their lifeтАЩs span has been run out, give up their bodies (by committing suicide). [It is only such suicide that is reprehensible]. It is considered quite desirable in the case of old men suffering from incurable diseases given up by the physicians; as has been thus declared:тАФтАШIf an old man,тАФincapable of purification and memory, who has passed beyond the reach of the physicianтАЩs art,тАФkills himself by falling down from a precipice, or entering into fire, or by fasting, or by drowning in water,тАФin his case there is impurity for three days; his bones being collected on the second day, on the third day the water offering-should be made, and on the fourth day the ┼Ъr─Бddha should be performedтАЩ. Suicide is regarded as desirable also in the case of persons suffering from leprosy and such other diseases; as has been said in connection with men who, though still in the HouseholderтАЩs state, have lost all energy,тАФтАШBent upon entering the Great Path, they do not wish to live on uselessly.тАЩ That man is called тАШdevoid of energyтАЩ who is incapable of doing purificatory acts, as also saying the Twilight Prayers &c. Then again, in texts deprecating suicide, the words used areтАФтАШif one whose body has not been emaciated, or who has not lost all energy, should kill himself &c. &c.тАЩ; which implies that it is permitted for those who are not such as here described.

Other Smс╣Ыti-texts prohibit the water-offering for other persons also. It has been thus declaredтАФтАШThose killed by kings, those killed by horned or fanged animals, or by serpents, and those who have abandoned themselves,тАФto these no ┼Ъr─Бddha is to be offered; and water, ball-offerings and other offerings that are made to the dead, all this does not reach them, it becomes lost in the intervening regions. Through fear of popular blame, one should make the N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa offering; and for the sake of these also food-grains, along with the additional fee, shall be given.тАЩ

Elsewhere againтАФ

тАШSinful men meet death from the C─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, from water, from serpents, from Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, from lightning and from fanged animals.тАЩ

It is also laid down thatтАФ

тАШFor incendiaries, for keepers of baths and makers of ornaments and for professional mourners, there is purification after the performance of two Taptakс╣Ыcchra penances. Hence for these no after-death rites shall be performed by others; even the name of such persons, or of their family, should not be pronounced. For truly fearful is the uttering of the name of such a great sinner, who has gone to the worst hells.тАЩ

It is in connection with the acts mentioned here that Saс╣Гvartn has prescribed the тАШS─БntapanaтАЩ penance; and Par─Б┼Ыara has laid down the тАШTaptakс╣ЫcchraтАЩ; and Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha has prescribed the тАШC─Бndr─Бyaс╣ЗaтАЩ along with the ^(тАШ)Taptakс╣ЫcchraтАЩ. But these differences may be ignored.

With reference to what has been said above regarding тАШthe death of sinnersтАЩ resulting from тАШthe C─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla, from water &c. &c.,тАЩ there arises the following questionтАФтАЬDoes this rule, regarding the non-performance of the ┼Ъr─Бddha and the performance of penance, pertain to the C─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla who kills himself intentionally?тАФor to one who is killed through carelessness, without intention?тАЭ

Why should this question arise?

(A) Well, Gautama (14.12) has saidтАФтАШIn the case of those dying from hunger, by a weapon, by fire, by poison, in water, in prison, or from a precipice,тАФit is only when it is unintentional.тАЩ While in the verse just quoted it is said simply, without any qualification тАШThose dying at the hands of the C─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бla &c.тАЩ And on account of the necessity of reconciling this with what has been said in the other Smс╣Ыti text regarding the case of тАШdying in waterтАЩ &c., it must be тАШintentional deathтАЩ that is meant. And the idea arises that by reason of тАШassociation,тАЩ the same should be the case with the others also.

(B) On the other hand, the verse quoted uses the term тАШsinfulтАЩ; and all sinful act has been prohibited; he who does what is prohibited is called тАШsinfulтАЩ. And a man becomes the тАШdoerтАЩ of an act through his own initiative, as also through the urging of another person. Now, death тАШfrom lightning, and the fanged and horned animalsтАЩ could never belong to the former category (i.e. this could never be intentional); and no one is ever urged by others to such death; nor are these means of dying employed by suicides, as holes, water and sword etc., are, and it is only if these were so, and the man were to kill himself by having recourse to these, that he could be the тАШself-sufficient agett (agent?),тАЩ of the act of тАШdying.тАЩ The truth therefore is that the man who comes by such death is understood to have been sinful in his previous life,тАФas is learnt from the scriptures; just as the possession of тАШblack teethтАЩ and the rest. If it be askedтАФтАШwhat is the use of this fact of the manтАЩs having been sinful in the past being indicated?тАЩ But in the case of persons with deficient limbs etc.,; their previous connection with sin is clearly indicated; and the expiatory rite to be performed in the case has been laid down by Va┼Ыiс╣гс╣нha, as consisting, in the case of some men, of the performance of two Kс╣Ыcchras, and in that of others, of something more.

(C) In reality however, the suicide having died, can have nothing to do with the performance of any rites. Or, if he be regarded as having commited a grievous sin, then, any person who may have entered into any kind of relationship with himтАФmarital, or friendly, or sacrificial,тАФwould also have to be regarded as sinful. But such is not the usage of cultured men. For as a matter of fact, people having relationship with suicides are not looked down upon in any way; nor do they perform any expiatory rites.

From this it follows that what is meant is intentional death.

(D) Some people, having read, in another Smс╣Ыti text, the wordsтАФтАШthose killed by cows and Br─Бhmaс╣Зas etc.тАЩтАФread the words тАШthose who have abandoned themselvesтАЩ apart by themselves, and seem to take up an entirely different position.

From all this (A, B, C and D) there arises the above-mentioned doubtтАФas to what is the right view.

The right view is that intentional suicides are what are meant;тАФwhy?тАФbecause of their being spoken of as тАШsinful.тАЩ The man who intentionally proceeds to set into activity the causes leading to his own death, wilfully disobeys the law that тАШno man shall by his own desire, cut off his life-span and it is only right that such a transgressor should be spoken of as тАШsinful.тАЩ

тАЬBut it has been said and pointed out above that the causes of death spoken of do not resemble the sword and other things used by suicides; so that the intentional killing of oneself could not be meant.тАЭ

Our answer to this is as follows:тАФIf a man does not guard himself against a danger, he is regarded to be as good as having brought it upon himself. So that if a man wanders about alone in a forest infested with c─Бс╣Зс╕Н─Бlas and robbers,тАФeven though he may not have the wish that they should kill him, yetтАФthere is disobedience of scriptures on his part, since he acts in a way that invites danger, and he does nothing to avert that danger. Similarly with the man who goes to swim in the river, or enters a boat of doubtful capacity rowed by incompetent boatsmen. Under such circumstances, if by the loss of vigour, or by the turning over of the boat, the man should happen to die, it would be only right to regard him as having committed a sin. On the contrary, if persons were to bathe in water, whose depth they have duly ascertained by means of sticks etc., and of the presence wherein of alligators and other animals they, are ignorant,тАФand were to be carried away by any such animals, no blame would attach to them. Similarly if one gets into a boat, which is well-fastened, and rowed by capable rowers, and proceeds to cross a swift stream,тАФif, on the sudden rising of a strong wind, the boat happen to be tossed on a whril (whirl?)-pool and capsize, and the man become drowned,тАФhe would not have transgressed the scriptures at all. Similarly again, if one did not carefully avoid places known to be infested with snakes, and being bitten by a snake were to die, he would have acted sinfully; not otherwise. Similarly if one does not run to a safe distance, on seeing a sharp-horned cow or an elephant, and become killed, he is rightly regarded as sinful. Similarly again if, when it is raining heavily and lightning is flashing, if one wanders about in desolate places and does not take shelter in a village or town,тАФhis action is reprehensible. While if the lightning should, by chance, happen to fall upon a man who is in the village, there would be nothing sinful on the part of the man. For these reasons it is always right and proper that the man should do all that has been laid down (for his safety).

The prohibiting of тАШwater-offeringsтАЩ should be taken as applicable to all kinds of after-death rites; for such is the view propounded in another Smс╣Ыti -text.тАФ(88)

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдЯрд┐рдкреНрдкрдиреНрдпрдГ

(Verse 89 of others.)

This verse is quoted in Apar─Бrka (p. 877);тАФin Madanap─Бrij─Бta (p. 406), which adds the following notes:тАФтАШVс╣Ыth─Бj─Бt─Бс╕етАЩ are those who do not perform the тАШFive Great SacrificesтАЩ;тАФтАШSaс╣Еkaraj─Бt─Бс╕етАЩ are those born of castes mixed in the reverse order;тАФin Smс╣Ыtis─Бroddh─Бra (p. 217), which reads тАШniv─Бpo na vidh─лyateтАЩ for the last foot and explains тАШniv─Бpaс╕етАЩ as ┼Ъr─Бddha-Tarpaс╣ЗaтАЩ,тАФin ┼Ъuddhikaumud─л, (p. 80), which explains тАШVс╣Ыth─Бsaс╣Еkaraj─БtaтАЩ as born of a lower caste father and higher caste mother;тАФand in H─Бralat─Б (p. 202), which has the same explanation and adds that such persons are precluded from all religious acts; it adds the following remarksтАФThose born of higher caste father and lower caste mothers are not called тАШVс╣Ыth─Бsaс╣Еkaraj─БtaтАЩ, as these persons are permitted to perform all religious acts to which their motherтАЩs caste is entitled,тАФтАШ─Бtmaty─БginтАЩ are those who have committed suicide by hanging or poison or some such means, or those who have renounced the duties of their caste.

рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рддреБрд▓реНрдп-рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рдирд┐

(verses 5.88-89)

Viс╣гс╣Зu (22.56).тАФтАШSuicides and outcasts do not cause impurity or receive offerings of water.тАЩ

Y─Бj├▒avalkya (3.6).тАФтАШThose who have recourse to heretics, thieves, women who have killed their husbands, loose women, and women drinking wine, and women killing themselves, do not partake of impurity or of water-offerings.тАЩ

Vс╣Ыddha-Manu (Apar─Бrka, p. 876).тАФтАШEunuchs and others should not make water-offerings, nor thieves and apostates, nor women who injure their embryo and husband, or drink wine.тАЩ

Vс╣Ыddha-Y─Бj├▒avalkya (Do.).тАФтАШPersons killed by lightning, bulls, kings, Br─Бhmaс╣Зas, water, horned animals, tusked animals or fire, persons born in vain, the eunuch, and the religious student are not deserving of water-offerings.тАЩ

─Аpastamba (Do., p. 877).тАФтАШOne who kills himself by means of fire, water and such things,тАФfor him there is no impurity; nor should water be offered to him.тАЩ

Gautama (Do.).тАФтАШFor those who intentionally kill themselves by starvation, or weapons, or fire or poison, or water (there shall be no offering).тАЩ

Aс╣Еgiras (Do.).тАФтАШIf one is killed, through carelessness, by fire, water and such things, for him impurity shall be observed and water-offerings made.тАЩ

B├╝hler

089 Libations of water shall not be offered to those who (neglect the prescribed rites and may be said to) have been born in vain, to those born in consequence of an illegal mixture of the castes, to those who are ascetics (of heretical sects), and to those who have committed suicide,

090 рдкрд╛рд╖рдгреНрдбрдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореН ...{Loading}...

рдкрд╛рд╖рдгреНрдбрдореН рдЖрд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЪ
рдЪрд░рдиреНрддреАрдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рдХрд╛рдорддрдГ ред
рдЧрд░реНрдн-рднрд░реНрддреГ-рджреНрд░реБрд╣рд╛рдВ рдЪреИрд╡
рд╕реБрд░рд╛рдкреАрдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рдпреЛрд╖рд┐рддрд╛рдореН рее рел.репреж рее [реореп рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдкрд╛рдареЗ]

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рд╖реН рдЯреАрдХрд╛рдГ ...{Loading}...
рдЧрдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдирде-рдореВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрдГ

Also from women, who have joined a heretic, who behave too freely, who have injured a child in their womb or their husband, and those who drink wineтАФ(89).

рдореЗрдзрд╛рддрд┐рдерд┐рдГ

рд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдкрд░рд┐рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧреЗрди рдмрд╛рд╣реНрдпрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпрдВ рдирд░рд╢рд┐рд░рдГрдХрдкрд╛рд▓рд░рдХреНрддрд╛рдореНрдмрд░рд╛рджрд┐рдзрд╛рд░рдгрдВ рдкрд╛рд╖рдгреНрдбрдореН, рддрджрд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрд╛рдГ рдХреГрддрддрд▓реНрд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧреНрдкрд░рд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рд╛рдГ рддрджреНрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╡рд╢рд╡рд░реНрддрд┐рдиреНрдпрдГ ред рдЪрд░рдиреНрддреАрдирд╛рдВ рдЪ рдХрд╛рдорддрдГ ред рддрджрд╛рдЪрд╛рд░рдХреБрд▓рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧреЗрдиреЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛рдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рдиреБрд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпреИрдХрд╛рдиреЗрдХрдкрд░рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕рдВрдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧрдГ205 рдХрд╛рдордЪрд╛рд░рдГ ред рднрд░реНрддреБрд░реН рд╡рд┐рд╖рдЧрд░рд╛рджрд┐рджрд╛рдиреЗрди рдЧрд░реНрднрд╕реНрдп рдЪ рдкрд╛рддрдирдВ рджреНрд░реЛрд╣рдГ ред рд╕реБрд░рд╛рдкреНрдпрдГ рдпрдерд╛рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рдкрд╛рддреЗрди ред

  • рдЕрддреНрд░ рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЖрд╣- “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреЛ рди рдкрд┐рдмреЗрддреН рд╕реБрд░рд╛рдореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕рддреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рдЬрд╛рддреНрдпрд░реНрдерд╛рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЗ рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рддреН рдкреБрдВрд╕ рдПрд╡ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдп рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЛ рди рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ рдЗрддрд┐ ред рдпрджреНрдпреН рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрдкреБрдВрд╕рдпреЛрд░реН рдПрдХрд╛ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рд╕реН рддрдерд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрддреНрд╡рдкреБрдВрд╕реНрддреНрд╡рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧреЗ рднрд┐рджреНрдпреЗрддреЗ ред рдЗрд╣ рдЪ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордг рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреБрдВрд▓реНрд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрд╕реНрдп рд╢рдмреНрджрд╕реНрдп рд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгрд╛рджреН рдЕрд╢реНрд░реБрддрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рдХрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрдГ ред рдпрдерд╛ “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреА рдкрд╛рдпрдпреЗрддреН рдкреБрддреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдердореН” рдЗрддрд┐ рди рдкреБрдВрд╕рдГ рдкрд╛рдпрдпреЗрджреН рдЗрддрд┐, рддрджреНрд╡рддреН рдкреБрдВрд▓реНрд▓рд┐рдЧрд╢реНрд░реБрддреМ рди рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдп рдЙрдкрд╛рджреАрдпрдиреНрддреЗ ред рдпрддреНрд░206 рдХреНрд╡рдЪрд┐рд▓реН рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрдВ рди рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ, рдпрде “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреЛ рди рд╣рдиреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ” рдЗрддрд┐ рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ рдЕрдкрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЛ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдпрддреЗ, рддрддреНрд░ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпрдпрд╛ рд╢реНрд░реБрддреНрдпрд╛ рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╕реНрдпреЗрдкреНрд╕рд┐рддрддрдорддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рдкреНрд░рд╛рдзрд╛рдиреНрдпрдореН ред рди рдЪ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдиреЗ рдкреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рдкрджрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХреЗрдгрд╛рдиреНрдпрд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрдерд╛ “рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдВ рд╕рдВрдорд╛рд░реНрд╖реНрдЯрд┐” рдЗрддрд┐ рдиреИрдХрд╕реНрдп рд╕рдВрдорд╛рд░реНрдЧрдГ ред рдЗрд╣ рдкреБрдирд░реН “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреЗрди рд╕реБрд░рд╛ рди рдкреЗрдпрд╛” рдЗрддрд┐ рдХрд░реНрддреГрддрдпрд╛ рд╕рд╛рдзрдирднрд╛рд╡реЗрди рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐ рдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢рд╛рддреН “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреЛ рди рдкрд┐рдмреЗрддреН рд╕реБрд░рд╛рдореН” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЖрдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрд╛рднрд┐рд╣рд┐рддреЗ рд╜рдкрд┐ рддрджрд░реНрдерд╛рдирд╛рдореН207 рдЕрдкрд┐ рд╡реГрддреНрддреЗрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рдкрджрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реНрдереЛрдкрдкрддреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рдердорд╛рдкрд┐ рддреГрддреАрдпрд╛рдиреБрдЧреБрдгреНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рдЧреБрдгреАрднрд╛рд╡рдГ,208 рдЧреБрдгреЗ рдЪ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рд╢реНрд░реБрддрдВ рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ ред рдпрдерд╛ “рдкрд╢реБрдирд╛ рдпрдЬреЗрдд” рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреБрдорд╛рдиреН рдкрд╢реБрд░реН рдЖрд▓рднреНрдпрддреЗ рдПрдХрд╢реН рдЪ ред
  • рдЕрддреНрд░реЛрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ ред рдирд╛рддреНрд░ рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпрд╛рддреГрддреАрдпреЗ рдЧреБрдгрдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирднрд╛рд╡реЗрдирд╛рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖рд╛рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖рдпреЛрдГ рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдореН, рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд░реНрд╣рд┐ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреНрдпрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреА ред рдпрджреН рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрдВ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрддрдпреЛрдкрдкрджреНрдпрддреЗ209 рддрджреН рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ, рдЕрдирдиреНрдпрдкрд░рд╢рдмреНрджрд╛рд╡рдЧрдореНрдпрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН ред рдпрддреН рддреНрд╡реН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреЛ рд╜рд╡рдЧрддрдореН рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдВ рд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рдЙрдкрд╛рджреАрдпрддреЗ, рддрджреН рдпрд╛рджреГрд╢рдореН рдПрд╡ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╛рд╡рдЧрддрдВ рддрд╛рджреГрд╢рдореН рдПрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдзреЗрдпрдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐рддрдпрд╛ рд╢рдмреНрджреЗрди рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрд╛рджреНрдпрддреЗ ред “рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгреЛ рди рд╣рдиреНрддрд╡реНрдпрдГ” рдЗрддреНрдпреН рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпреЗ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдз рдПрд╡ рдкрд░реНрдпрд╡рд╕реНрдпрддрд┐, рдпрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН рддрджреН рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреЛ рд╜рд╡рдЧрддрдореН ред рдкреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рдкрджрд┐рдХрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖рд╛ рддреБ рд╢реНрд░реБрддреНрдпрд╛рдирд░реНрдердХреНрдпрдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рддреН ред рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛рджреЗрд╕реН рддреБ рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реНрдп рдирд╛рдиреНрддрд░реАрдпрдХрддреНрд╡реЗрдирд╛рдкреНрдпреН рдЙрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдирд╕рдВрднрд╡рд╛рджреН рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖рд╛рд╡рд┐рд╡рдХреНрд╖реЗ рдЙрдЪреНрдпреЗрддреЗ ред рддрддреНрд░реЗрд╣ рди рдмреНрд░рд╛рд╣реНрдордгрд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рдГ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЛ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдирд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддреНрдпрдГ, рддрджреНрджреНрд╡реЗрд╖рд╛рддреН210 рд╕реНрд╡рддрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддреЗрдГ, рддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрдп рдЪрд╛рддреНрд░ рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рдкреНрд░рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рддреН ред рди рд╣реНрдпреН рдЕрд╡рд┐рдзреАрдпрдорд╛рдирдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзрдГ рдХрдердВрдЪрд┐рджреН рдЕрдиреНрд╡реЗрддреБрдореН рдЕрд▓рдореН ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддреНрдпрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреН, рдЕрдХрд╛рд░рдХрддреНрд╡рд╛рджреН рдЕрдХрд╛рд░рдХрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡рд╛рдиреБрдкреНрд░рд╡реЗрд╢реЗрдирд╛рдкрд┐ рд╕рдВрдмрдиреНрдзрдВ рди211 рд▓рднреНрдпрддреЗ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреН рдЕрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрд╡рдпрд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрднрд╛рд╡ рдПрд╖рд┐рддрд╡реНрдпрдГ ред рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдВрд╢реН рдЪ рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рдирд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреАрдХреГрддреЗрди рднрд╛рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдереЛ рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрддрдпрд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗ ред рднрд╛рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдерд╢реН рдЪ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╖реЗрдзреЗрди рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╛рдВрд╢рд╕реНрдп рдЧреГрд╣реАрддрддреНрд╡рд╛рддреН рддрддрдГ рдкреНрд░рдЪреНрдпреБрддреЛ рд▓реМрдХрд┐рдХреНрдпрд╛212 рдЪ рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╛рдиреБрд╖реНрдард╛рди рдЖрддреНрдорд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердореН рдЕрдиреБрдкреНрд░реЗрд╡реЗрд╢рдореН рдЕрдкреНрдпреН рдЕрдХрд╛рдВрдХреНрд╖рдиреНрдиреН рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╕рд╛рдкреЗрдХреНрд╖рд╡рд┐рдзреМ рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рддрдГ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдкрдиреНрдирд╣рдирдирдХрд░реНрддреГрднрд╛рд╡рд╕реНрдп рдкреБрдВрд╕реЛ
